title: Indian Constitution - Overview
content:
# Indian Constitution - Overview

## Basic Facts
- **Adopted**: November 26, 1949
- **Came into effect**: January 26, 1950
- **Drafting Committee Chairman**: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar
- **Constituent Assembly President**: Dr. Rajendra Prasad
- **Time taken to draft**: 2 years, 11 months, 18 days

## Structure of Constitution
- **Original**: 395 Articles, 8 Schedules, 22 Parts
- **Current**: 448 Articles, 12 Schedules, 25 Parts

## Key Features

### 1. Longest Written Constitution
Most detailed and comprehensive constitution in the world.

### 2. Blend of Rigidity and Flexibility
- Some provisions can be amended by simple majority
- Some need special majority
- Some need ratification by states

### 3. Federal with Unitary Bias
- Division of powers between Centre and States
- Strong Centre with emergency provisions

### 4. Parliamentary System
- President: Nominal head
- Prime Minister: Real executive authority
- Cabinet responsible to Legislature

### 5. Single Citizenship
Unlike USA, India has only single citizenship.

### 6. Independent Judiciary
Supreme Court at apex, independent of executive.

## Sources of Constitution

| Feature | Borrowed From |
|---------|---------------|
| Parliamentary System | Britain |
| Fundamental Rights | USA |
| Directive Principles | Ireland |
| Federal Structure | Canada |
| Emergency Provisions | Germany |
| Amendment Procedure | South Africa |
| Concurrent List | Australia |
| Fundamental Duties | USSR |

## Preamble
"We, the people of India, having solemnly resolved to constitute India into a SOVEREIGN SOCIALIST SECULAR DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC..."

### Key Words in Preamble
- **Sovereign**: Supreme power
- **Socialist**: Social and economic equality (added 1976)
- **Secular**: No state religion (added 1976)
- **Democratic**: Government by people
- **Republic**: Elected head of state

## Important Parts
- Part III: Fundamental Rights (Art 12-35)
- Part IV: Directive Principles (Art 36-51)
- Part IVA: Fundamental Duties (Art 51A)
- Part V: The Union (Art 52-151)
- Part VI: The States (Art 152-237)
- Part XVIII: Emergency Provisions (Art 352-360)

title: Fundamental Rights (Part III)
content:
# Fundamental Rights (Part III: Articles 12-35)

## Overview
- Originally 7 Fundamental Rights (now 6)
- Right to Property removed by 44th Amendment (1978)
- Can be suspended during Emergency (except Art 20 & 21)

## Six Fundamental Rights

### 1. Right to Equality (Articles 14-18)

| Article | Right |
|---------|-------|
| 14 | Equality before law |
| 15 | No discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth |
| 16 | Equal opportunity in public employment |
| 17 | Abolition of untouchability |
| 18 | Abolition of titles |

### 2. Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22)

**Article 19** - Six Freedoms:
1. Speech and expression
2. Assemble peacefully without arms
3. Form associations/unions
4. Move freely throughout India
5. Reside and settle anywhere in India
6. Practice any profession/occupation

**Article 20**: Protection against conviction
**Article 21**: Protection of life and personal liberty
**Article 21A**: Right to Education (6-14 years)
**Article 22**: Protection against arrest and detention

### 3. Right Against Exploitation (Articles 23-24)

| Article | Protection Against |
|---------|--------------------|
| 23 | Human trafficking, forced labor |
| 24 | Child labor (below 14 years in factories) |

### 4. Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28)

| Article | Right |
|---------|-------|
| 25 | Freedom of conscience, practice religion |
| 26 | Manage religious affairs |
| 27 | No tax for promotion of any religion |
| 28 | No religious instruction in state-funded institutions |

### 5. Cultural & Educational Rights (Articles 29-30)

| Article | Right |
|---------|-------|
| 29 | Protection of minorities' culture |
| 30 | Minorities' right to establish educational institutions |

### 6. Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32)

Dr. Ambedkar called it "Heart and Soul of Constitution"

## Writs Under Article 32

| Writ | Purpose |
|------|----------|
| Habeas Corpus | "Produce the body" - Against illegal detention |
| Mandamus | "We command" - To perform public duty |
| Prohibition | Stop lower court from exceeding jurisdiction |
| Certiorari | Transfer case to higher court |
| Quo Warranto | "By what authority" - Challenge illegal office holder |

title: Indian Parliament
content:
# Indian Parliament

## Structure
Parliament = President + Lok Sabha + Rajya Sabha

## Lok Sabha (House of People)

### Composition
- Maximum strength: 552
- Elected members: 530 (States) + 20 (UTs)
- Nominated: 2 (Anglo-Indian) - Abolished in 2020
- Current strength: 543

### Important Facts
| Feature | Detail |
|---------|--------|
| Term | 5 years |
| Quorum | 1/10 of total members |
| Presiding Officer | Speaker |
| Minimum age | 25 years |
| First Speaker | G.V. Mavalankar |
| First Woman Speaker | Meira Kumar |

### Exclusive Powers
- Money bills can only be introduced here
- No confidence motion against government
- Financial matters

## Rajya Sabha (Council of States)

### Composition
- Maximum strength: 250
- Elected: 238 (by State MLAs)
- Nominated: 12 (by President)

### Important Facts
| Feature | Detail |
|---------|--------|
| Term | 6 years (1/3 retire every 2 years) |
| Quorum | 1/10 of total members |
| Presiding Officer | Vice President |
| Minimum age | 30 years |
| First Chairman | Dr. S. Radhakrishnan |

### Special Powers
- Cannot be dissolved
- Can declare state subject as national importance (Art 249)
- Create All India Services (Art 312)

## Types of Bills

| Bill Type | Introduction | Passage |
|-----------|--------------|----------|
| Ordinary Bill | Either House | Both Houses |
| Money Bill | Lok Sabha only | RS has 14 days to suggest |
| Financial Bill | Lok Sabha only | Varies |
| Constitutional Amendment | Either House | Special majority |

## Joint Session (Article 108)
- Called when disagreement between Houses
- Presided by Lok Sabha Speaker
- Decision by majority of total members present
- Not for Money Bills or Constitutional Amendments

## Parliamentary Sessions
1. **Budget Session**: February-May
2. **Monsoon Session**: July-August
3. **Winter Session**: November-December

## Important Committees
- Public Accounts Committee
- Estimates Committee
- Committee on Public Undertakings
- Joint Parliamentary Committee

title: Indian Judiciary System
content:
# Indian Judiciary System

## Structure
- Supreme Court (Apex)
- High Courts (State level)
- District Courts (District level)
- Lower Courts (Taluka/Town level)

## Supreme Court of India

### Basic Facts
| Feature | Detail |
|---------|--------|
| Established | January 28, 1950 |
| Location | New Delhi |
| First CJI | H.J. Kania |
| Sanctioned Judges | 34 (including CJI) |
| Retirement Age | 65 years |

### Appointment of Judges
- CJI: President appoints senior-most judge
- Other judges: President appoints on CJI's recommendation
- Collegium System: CJI + 4 senior judges

### Jurisdiction

#### 1. Original Jurisdiction (Article 131)
- Disputes between Centre and States
- Disputes between States

#### 2. Appellate Jurisdiction
- Constitutional matters
- Civil matters
- Criminal matters

#### 3. Advisory Jurisdiction (Article 143)
President can seek SC's opinion on legal matters.

#### 4. Writ Jurisdiction (Article 32)
Can issue writs for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

### Judicial Review
Power to examine constitutionality of laws.

## High Courts

### Basic Facts
| Feature | Detail |
|---------|--------|
| Total High Courts | 25 |
| First HC | Calcutta (1862) |
| Retirement Age | 62 years |

### Jurisdiction
- Original (Art 226): Writs for any matter
- Appellate: Appeals from lower courts
- Supervisory: Over subordinate courts

## Important Judicial Terms

| Term | Meaning |
|------|----------|
| PIL | Public Interest Litigation |
| Curative Petition | Last resort after review petition |
| Contempt of Court | Disobedience of court orders |
| Suo Motu | Action on court's own motion |
| Amicus Curiae | Friend of Court |

## Constitutional Provisions
- Article 124-147: Supreme Court
- Article 214-231: High Courts
- Article 233-237: Subordinate Courts

## Landmark Judgments
- Kesavananda Bharati (1973): Basic Structure Doctrine
- Maneka Gandhi (1978): Right to Life expanded
- Vishaka Guidelines (1997): Sexual harassment at workplace
- NALSA vs Union of India (2014): Transgender rights

title: Important Constitutional Bodies
content:
# Important Constitutional Bodies

## Election Commission of India

### Constitutional Provision: Article 324

| Feature | Detail |
|---------|--------|
| Established | 1950 |
| Composition | CEC + 2 Election Commissioners |
| Appointment | By President |
| Tenure | 6 years or 65 years (whichever earlier) |
| First CEC | Sukumar Sen |

### Functions
- Conduct elections to Parliament, State Legislatures, President, Vice President
- Prepare electoral rolls
- Recognition of political parties
- Model Code of Conduct

## Union Public Service Commission (UPSC)

### Constitutional Provision: Article 315-323

| Feature | Detail |
|---------|--------|
| Established | 1926 (as PSC) |
| Composition | Chairman + Members |
| Appointment | By President |
| Tenure | 6 years or 65 years |

### Functions
- Conduct Civil Services Examinations
- Advise government on recruitment
- Disciplinary matters of civil servants

## Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG)

### Constitutional Provision: Article 148-151

| Feature | Detail |
|---------|--------|
| Appointment | By President |
| Tenure | 6 years or 65 years |
| Removal | Same as SC Judge |
| First CAG | V. Narahari Rao |

### Functions
- Audit government accounts
- Guardian of public purse
- Reports to President/Governor

## Finance Commission

### Constitutional Provision: Article 280

| Feature | Detail |
|---------|--------|
| Chairman + 4 Members | |
| Constituted every 5 years | |
| Current (16th) | Arvind Panagariya |

### Functions
- Distribution of taxes between Centre and States
- Grants-in-aid to States
- Financial matters referred by President

## Attorney General of India

### Constitutional Provision: Article 76

| Feature | Detail |
|---------|--------|
| Appointment | By President |
| Qualification | Same as SC Judge |
| Not fixed tenure | Holds office during President's pleasure |

### Functions
- Chief legal advisor to Government
- Appears on behalf of Government in Supreme Court
- Right to speak in Parliament (but no vote)

## Other Bodies

| Body | Article | Function |
|------|---------|----------|
| State PSC | 315-323 | State level recruitment |
| Advocate General | 165 | State's legal advisor |
| National Commission for SCs | 338 | Safeguard SC interests |
| National Commission for STs | 338A | Safeguard ST interests |
